blog.description: We are enthusiastic and fantasy oriented people. We will deliver you all the stories and lore you need for your favorite fantasy universe, TV series, books, comics, and games.

summary: Game of Thrones Lore: History and Geography of House Justman
title: Game of Thrones Lore: History and Geography of House Justman
excerpt: House Justman was a noble house from the riverlands who ruled as Kings of the Trident (or Kings of the Rivers and the Hills). According to semi-canon sources they blazoned their arms with golden scales on white, a double tressure blue.

blog.name: the-dark-judge
blog.title: Pack Hunter
blog.description: Far Cry 5 / New Dawn sideblog with lots of love for the Seed Bros.

body:
Too many Johns

My dad’s name is John, then there’s Jon Snow, there’s also John Seed.

My dad finds it hilarious when I get mad and/or annoyed at the ‘Not-Him-Johns’ because:

Me, grumbling at the TV, playing an Arcade map: Damnhellsonofbitch fuuuck offf John…

My dad, from the kitchen, waving a spoon at me threateningly: First of all, how fucking rude…

Me: Second of all?

Dad: Chicken or steak for dinner?


This is the same man who tossed snow on himself and proclaimed he was Jon Snow.

Me: Second of all?

blog.name: asongofstarkandtargaryen
blog.title: Dracarys!
blog.description: Jon/Dany/Bran/Arya Stan. Salty about the got ending. Also likes: The 100,  Star Wars, Stranger Things.

question: 🔥 jonrya as a romantic ship
answer:
I don’t ship Jonrya but the relationship Arya and Jon share is my absolutely favourite one. I think Martin has also made a comment on the subject of the importance of Arya and Jon’s relationship and the countless times these two think of each other (more times than any pov character thinks of another pov character) just prove how crucial this bond is to their journeys and to the story overall.

While I personally don’t ship it romantically I think it’s wrong that some fans label it a crack ship, especially on the books. I mean Martín even revealed on the 1993 letter that his original plans were for Jon and Arya to end up together and as King and Queen of Westeros -whether or not this will actually happen on the last two books remains to be seen(personally I believe that Martin changed his original plans and that a romantic relationship won’t happen between those two).

Finally, I have to say that I love the majority of Jonrya shippers. These folks have great understanding of Jon and Arya’s personalities and write some of the best meta about them. At first I was hesitant to talk to them, despite adoring the same duo with them, because I thought that they wouldn’t like to underact with people who don’t ship their pairing. But they are so friendly and nice and they have no problem interacting even with people like me who ship a rival pairing. A 11/10 shipping community.

summary: “If she had only married Rhaegar as the gods intended, he would never have looked twice at the wolf girl. Rhaegar would be our...
caption:
“If she had only married Rhaegar as the gods intended, he would never have looked twice at the wolf girl. Rhaegar would be our king today and I would be his queen, the mother of his sons.

She had never forgiven Robert for killing him.”

tags: i went to bed last night thinking about this
i had to get it off my chest
summary: When I think about the fact that in this show, the two characters that were so far removed from what we all believed to be the...
body:
When I think about the fact that in this show, the two characters that were so far removed from what we all believed to be the actual core of the shows plotline, have come forth and joined each other to defeat the big bad that no one really cared too much about until season 5, is just so breathtakingly beautiful.

I never thought that the timid blonde on the other side of the world and the broody man at the end of it were ever going to converge, unite and fall in love. That is powerful storytelling right there and it just hits me in my feelings. So hard. Looking back to my first time watching the show and how I didn’t really give either a second thought and then 8 season later they are at the center of it all fighting for everyone and everything, it’s just gets me so emotional. That’s why I love them, this show, and will always have a place in my heart for them and this story.

summary: I love the Starks so much it hurts. I love Jon, Sansa, Arya & Bran so so much. And those who are gone- Rickon, Robb, Ned, Benjen...
body: I love the Starks so much it hurts. I love Jon, Sansa, Arya & Bran so so much. And those who are gone- Rickon, Robb, Ned, Benjen and Cat. I love this family so much & I hope they get a happy ending. It’s what they deserve.

summary: Rewatching GoT 7x05, specifically the scene with the Tarlys, I’m just wondering...why does Daenerys get so much hate for this...
body:
Rewatching GoT 7x05, specifically the scene with the Tarlys, I’m just wondering…why does Daenerys get so much hate for this when Jon did the same thing with Janos Slynt? 

Obviously from a modern perspective, executing someone because they refuse to bend the knee to you is not an okay thing to do. But I don’t think it’s fair to hold characters in the medieval inspired world of Westeros to modern standards, and I think a lot of other characters in Dany’s position would have done the same thing. Stannis burnt Mance Rayder alive for not bending the knee to him, but the fandom still loves Stannis. 

Now, let’s talk about Jon. I think all of us can agree that in the modern day and age, insubordination is not just cause for execution. However, this isn’t the modern age, this is a medieval fantasy world, and Jon gave Janos Slynt a chance to change his stance, which he refused to back down from. Thus, he was punished accordingly. And, in part, it was also to make an example of him. Jon needed to show that he was serious as a leader - he was not going to make idle threats. Even though Slynt begged for mercy at the end of his life, Jon followed through and cut off Slynt’s head. 

We celebrated Janos Slynt’s death because he was a bad person. He helped Littlefinger betray Ned Stark, leading to Ned’s unjust execution. He was a literal child killer, helping to orchestrate the murders of Robert Baratheon’s bastards on Joffrey’s orders, and he personally killed Barra - an infant - just because Robert was her biological father. In the books it is also mentioned that Slynt can be bought, accepting bribes and selling positions during his time as Commander of the City Watch. Janos Slynt was, undeniably, scum of the earth. 

But that’s not why Jon kills him. Jon kills him because he refused to accept Jon’s orders and, when given an opportunity to back down, he persisted.

Let’s compare that to Daenerys’s execution of Randyll Tarly. Randyll Tarly was an absolutely horrible person. First of all, he was an abusive father to Sam simply because Sam, being kind and intelligent, did not conform to Randyll’s toxic ideas of masculinity. Randyll has a deep seated hatred of the feminine, and he can’t stand that Sam doesn’t adhere to his idea of what a man should be. 

A dozen masters-at-arms came and went at Horn Hill, trying to turn Samwell into the knight his father wanted. The boy was cursed and caned, slapped and starved. One man had him sleep in his chainmail to make him more martial. Another dressed him in his mother’s clothing and paraded him through the bailey to shame him into valor. He only grew fatter and more frightened, until Lord Randyll’s disappointment turned to anger and then to loathing. “One time,” Sam confided, his voice dropping from a whisper, “two men came to the castle, warlocks from Qarth with white skin and blue lips. They slaughtered a bull aurochs and made me bathe in the hot blood, but it didn’t make me brave as they’d promised. I got sick and retched. Father had them scourged.” - AGoT, Jon IV

When Randyll cannot succeed in making Sam “manly enough”, he tells Sam that he has a choice: either he will join the Night’s Watch, or Randyll will kill him. His own son. (Hey, Randyll gave a choice to Sam between compliance or death, and Daenerys did the same to him. Funny how karma works!) Randyll’s general horribleness continues when he is incredibly misogynistic towards Brienne in AFFC. 

“As for you, my lady, it is said that your father is a good man. If so, I pity him. Some men are blessed with sons, some with daughters. No man deserves to be cursed with such as you.”
…
“Go where you want and do as you will … but when you’re raped don’t look to me for justice. You will have earned it with your folly.” - AFFC, Brienne III

Randyll is also a xenophobe. He hates the Free Folk just because they were born on the other side of the Wall, calls Gilly a whore the first time he meets her, and in that scene with Daenerys, you know what he says? 

“Say what you will about [Cersei], she was born in Westeros.” 

SHE. WAS. BORN. HERE. That xenophobic garbage is his justification. 

Randyll is a horrible person just like Janos Slynt was, and they both deserved to die. Yes Daenerys doesn’t execute Randyll for being horrible, she executes him for not obeying her, but so does Jon with Janos Slynt. 

Now, what about Dickon you might say? Surely Dickon did not deserve to die with his father? I’ll admit, I feel bad for Dickon. He didn’t seem like a cruel kid, but the thing is…Dickon was also complicit in treason. He and Randyll aligned themselves with the Lannisters, going against their oath sworn to House Tyrell, and were complicit in Olenna’s murder. Even Tyrion says in this scene that the Tarlys’ allegiances must be flexible if they were willing to do such a thing. How honorable can they really be if they’re willing to betray their lords? 

The Tarlys were given the choice to bend the knee. They refused to. They were given a choice to go the Wall, and they refused. Maybe some people see Dany’s actions as wrong because she chooses to execute them by dragonfire, not by beheading, but in my opinion, it doesn’t matter how someone dies. It doesn’t matter if you cut their head off, or burn them with dragonfire, or slay them in battle. You’re taking a life no matter how you choose to do it. There is no method that makes that “better”. But this is war, and almost every character on this show has killed an enemy at some point. However they chose to do it, it’s still murder. 

And in the end, what else was there to be done? Daenerys and Tyrion gave the Tarlys a choice. And they made it.

reblog.comment:

…
“Go where you want and do as you will … but when you’re raped don’t look to me for justice. You will have earned it with your folly.” - AFFC, Brienne III

Randyll is also a xenophobe. He hates the Free Folk just because they were born on the other side of the Wall, calls Gilly a whore the first time he meets her, and in that scene with Daenerys, you know what he says? 

“Say what you will about [Cersei], she was born in Westeros.” 

SHE. WAS. BORN. HERE. That xenophobic garbage is his justification. 

Randyll is a horrible person just like Janos Slynt was, and they both deserved to die. Yes Daenerys doesn’t execute Randyll for being horrible, she executes him for not obeying her, but so does Jon with Janos Slynt. 

Now, what about Dickon you might say? Surely Dickon did not deserve to die with his father? I’ll admit, I feel bad for Dickon. He didn’t seem like a cruel kid, but the thing is…Dickon was also complicit in treason. He and Randyll aligned themselves with the Lannisters, going against their oath sworn to House Tyrell, and were complicit in Olenna’s murder. Even Tyrion says in this scene that the Tarlys’ allegiances must be flexible if they were willing to do such a thing. How honorable can they really be if they’re willing to betray their lords? 

The Tarlys were given the choice to bend the knee. They refused to. They were given a choice to go the Wall, and they refused. Maybe some people see Dany’s actions as wrong because she chooses to execute them by dragonfire, not by beheading, but in my opinion, it doesn’t matter how someone dies. It doesn’t matter if you cut their head off, or burn them with dragonfire, or slay them in battle. You’re taking a life no matter how you choose to do it. There is no method that makes that “better”. But this is war, and almost every character on this show has killed an enemy at some point. However they chose to do it, it’s still murder. 

And in the end, what else was there to be done? Daenerys and Tyrion gave the Tarlys a choice. And they made it.

trail.content_raw:
Rewatching GoT 7x05, specifically the scene with the Tarlys, I’m just wondering…why does Daenerys get so much hate for this when Jon did the same thing with Janos Slynt? 

Obviously from a modern perspective, executing someone because they refuse to bend the knee to you is not an okay thing to do. But I don’t think it’s fair to hold characters in the medieval inspired world of Westeros to modern standards, and I think a lot of other characters in Dany’s position would have done the same thing. Stannis burnt Mance Rayder alive for not bending the knee to him, but the fandom still loves Stannis. 

Now, let’s talk about Jon. I think all of us can agree that in the modern day and age, insubordination is not just cause for execution. However, this isn’t the modern age, this is a medieval fantasy world, and Jon gave Janos Slynt a chance to change his stance, which he refused to back down from. Thus, he was punished accordingly. And, in part, it was also to make an example of him. Jon needed to show that he was serious as a leader - he was not going to make idle threats. Even though Slynt begged for mercy at the end of his life, Jon followed through and cut off Slynt’s head. 

We celebrated Janos Slynt’s death because he was a bad person. He helped Littlefinger betray Ned Stark, leading to Ned’s unjust execution. He was a literal child killer, helping to orchestrate the murders of Robert Baratheon’s bastards on Joffrey’s orders, and he personally killed Barra - an infant - just because Robert was her biological father. In the books it is also mentioned that Slynt can be bought, accepting bribes and selling positions during his time as Commander of the City Watch. Janos Slynt was, undeniably, scum of the earth. 

But that’s not why Jon kills him. Jon kills him because he refused to accept Jon’s orders and, when given an opportunity to back down, he persisted.

Let’s compare that to Daenerys’s execution of Randyll Tarly. Randyll Tarly was an absolutely horrible person. First of all, he was an abusive father to Sam simply because Sam, being kind and intelligent, did not conform to Randyll’s toxic ideas of masculinity. Randyll has a deep seated hatred of the feminine, and he can’t stand that Sam doesn’t adhere to his idea of what a man should be. 

A dozen masters-at-arms came and went at Horn Hill, trying to turn Samwell into the knight his father wanted. The boy was cursed and caned, slapped and starved. One man had him sleep in his chainmail to make him more martial. Another dressed him in his mother’s clothing and paraded him through the bailey to shame him into valor. He only grew fatter and more frightened, until Lord Randyll’s disappointment turned to anger and then to loathing. “One time,” Sam confided, his voice dropping from a whisper, “two men came to the castle, warlocks from Qarth with white skin and blue lips. They slaughtered a bull aurochs and made me bathe in the hot blood, but it didn’t make me brave as they’d promised. I got sick and retched. Father had them scourged.” - AGoT, Jon IV

When Randyll cannot succeed in making Sam “manly enough”, he tells Sam that he has a choice: either he will join the Night’s Watch, or Randyll will kill him. His own son. (Hey, Randyll gave a choice to Sam between compliance or death, and Daenerys did the same to him. Funny how karma works!) Randyll’s general horribleness continues when he is incredibly misogynistic towards Brienne in AFFC. 

“As for you, my lady, it is said that your father is a good man. If so, I pity him. Some men are blessed with sons, some with daughters. No man deserves to be cursed with such as you.”
…
“Go where you want and do as you will … but when you’re raped don’t look to me for justice. You will have earned it with your folly.” - AFFC, Brienne III

Randyll is also a xenophobe. He hates the Free Folk just because they were born on the other side of the Wall, calls Gilly a whore the first time he meets her, and in that scene with Daenerys, you know what he says? 

“Say what you will about [Cersei], she was born in Westeros.” 

SHE. WAS. BORN. HERE. That xenophobic garbage is his justification. 

Randyll is a horrible person just like Janos Slynt was, and they both deserved to die. Yes Daenerys doesn’t execute Randyll for being horrible, she executes him for not obeying her, but so does Jon with Janos Slynt. 

Now, what about Dickon you might say? Surely Dickon did not deserve to die with his father? I’ll admit, I feel bad for Dickon. He didn’t seem like a cruel kid, but the thing is…Dickon was also complicit in treason. He and Randyll aligned themselves with the Lannisters, going against their oath sworn to House Tyrell, and were complicit in Olenna’s murder. Even Tyrion says in this scene that the Tarlys’ allegiances must be flexible if they were willing to do such a thing. How honorable can they really be if they’re willing to betray their lords? 

The Tarlys were given the choice to bend the knee. They refused to. They were given a choice to go the Wall, and they refused. Maybe some people see Dany’s actions as wrong because she chooses to execute them by dragonfire, not by beheading, but in my opinion, it doesn’t matter how someone dies. It doesn’t matter if you cut their head off, or burn them with dragonfire, or slay them in battle. You’re taking a life no matter how you choose to do it. There is no method that makes that “better”. But this is war, and almost every character on this show has killed an enemy at some point. However they chose to do it, it’s still murder. 

And in the end, what else was there to be done? Daenerys and Tyrion gave the Tarlys a choice. And they made it.
trail.content:
Rewatching GoT 7x05, specifically the scene with the Tarlys, I’m just wondering…why does Daenerys get so much hate for this when Jon did the same thing with Janos Slynt? 

Obviously from a modern perspective, executing someone because they refuse to bend the knee to you is not an okay thing to do. In the books it is also mentioned that Slynt can be bought, accepting bribes and selling positions during his time as Commander of the City Watch. Janos Slynt was, undeniably, scum of the earth.

One man had him sleep in his chainmail to make him more martial. Another dressed him in his mother’s clothing and paraded him through the bailey to shame him into valor. He only grew fatter and more frightened, until Lord Randyll’s disappointment turned to anger and then to loathing. “One time,” Sam confided, his voice dropping from a whisper, “two men came to the castle, warlocks from Qarth with white skin and blue lips. They slaughtered a bull aurochs and made me bathe in the hot blood, but it didn’t make me brave as they’d promised. I got sick and retched. Father had them scourged.” - AGoT, Jon IV

“As for you, my lady, it is said that your father is a good man. If so, I pity him. Some men are blessed with sons, some with daughters. No man deserves to be cursed with such as you.”
…
“Go where you want and do as you will … but when you’re raped don’t look to me for justice. You will have earned it with your folly.” - AFFC, Brienne III

Randyll is also a xenophobe. He hates the Free Folk just because they were born on the other side of the Wall, calls Gilly a whore the first time he meets her, and in that scene with Daenerys, you know what he says?
